titleStmt.title: Walter Jennings et al. to Beriah Magoffin
CWG10458

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p:
To His Excellency
B Magoffin
Governor of Ky.

Your Petitioner Walter Jennings would respectfully state that he is confined in the work house in the city of Louisville -- on account of his a fine for a breach of the peace -- On the day of 1861 he was tried in the City Court of Louisville for a fight with McGuire -- He was not in fault -- it was a small matter, no serious injury was done -- but your Petitioner was fined $25, & costs -- He is very poor & has a wife & two small children who will have to go to the Almshouse unless your petitioner is released.
He prays the Clemency of your excellency to remit his fine & let him work for bread for his wife & children and he will not offend against the peace.
We the under signed unite in the prayer of this petition

W. J. Lewis,
Robert. F. Baird
J. G. Wilson
H. S. Blair
Wm A Cocky
E Campbell
W C Price
James. W. Osborne
Robert Miller
Thos,, Rush
T H Crawford
W, C, D, Whips

Please direct answer to Michl. Murphy
Louisville
Kentucky
